title: The Covenant Renewed
shortSummary: Deuteronomy 29 records Moses renewing the covenant between God and Israel as they prepare to enter the Promised Land. The chapter emphasizes God's faithfulness in leading Israel, the seriousness of covenant obedience, and the consequences of turning away from God. It serves as a solemn reminder of Israel's unique relationship with God and the blessings and curses tied to their covenantal faithfulness.
timeline: c. 1406 BC - Israel's wilderness period, just before entering the Promised Land

keyCharacters.name: Moses
keyCharacters.description: The leader and prophet who speaks to Israel, reminding them of God's faithfulness and calling them to covenant obedience.

keyCharacters.name: Sihon
keyCharacters.description: King of Heshbon who opposed Israel and was defeated as they approached the Promised Land.

keyCharacters.name: Og
keyCharacters.description: King of Bashan who also fought against Israel and was defeated, with his land given as inheritance to Israel.

definitions.definition: A solemn agreement between God and His people involving promises and obligations.
Symbolic terms for bitterness and sorrow, representing the consequences of turning away from God.
Sulfur used in the Bible to describe divine judgment and destruction, notably in Sodom and Gomorrah.
A foreigner or non-Israelite residing among the Israelites, included in the covenant community.

outline.heading: Introduction and Reminder of God's Faithfulness
outline.description: Moses recalls God's mighty acts in Egypt and the wilderness, emphasizing His provision and guidance over 40 years to prepare Israel for the covenant.

outline.heading: Victory Over Kings and Land Distribution
outline.description: Moses recounts the defeat of Sihon and Og and the allocation of their lands to the tribes of Reuben, Gad, and half of Manasseh as a fulfillment of God's promises.

outline.heading: Call to Covenant Obedience
outline.description: All Israel, including leaders, families, and foreigners, are called to uphold the covenant, emphasizing its communal and generational nature.

outline.heading: Warning Against Idolatry and Apostasy
outline.description: Moses warns against turning to the idols of surrounding nations, describing the severe consequences for those who forsake the covenant.

outline.heading: Consequences for Future Generations
outline.description: The chapter describes how future generations will witness the judgment on the land and people who break the covenant, including exile and devastation.

outline.heading: Conclusion: The Secret and Revealed Things
outline.description: Moses concludes by distinguishing between God's secret purposes and the revealed commands given to Israel, underscoring the responsibility to obey God's law.

application: Commit to faithfully obeying God's covenant commands as a demonstration of love and loyalty to Him.
Recognize the seriousness of turning away from God and avoid any form of idolatry or compromise in your walk with Him.
Include all members of the community, including family and others in your sphere, in the pursuit of godly living and covenant faithfulness.
Trust in God's faithfulness to provide, guide, and protect His people as He did for Israel in the wilderness.

keyVerses.text: Keep therefore the words of this covenant, and do them, that ye may prosper in all that ye do.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the direct link between covenant obedience and God's blessing and prosperity.

keyVerses.text: Lest there should be among you man, or woman, or family, or tribe, whose heart turneth away this day from the LORD our God, to go and serve the gods of these nations; lest there should be among you a root that beareth gall and wormwood;
keyVerses.significance: It warns of the danger and bitterness of apostasy within the covenant community.

keyVerses.text: The LORD will not spare him, but then the anger of the LORD and his jealousy shall smoke against that man, and all the curses that are written in this book shall lie upon him, and the LORD shall blot out his name from under heaven.
keyVerses.significance: This verse underscores the severity of God's judgment on those who reject the covenant.

keyVerses.text: The secret things belong unto the LORD our God: but those things which are revealed belong unto us and to our children for ever, that we may do all the words of this law.
keyVerses.significance: It reminds believers to focus on obeying God's revealed word while trusting His sovereign wisdom in hidden matters.
